Innovation: Modern tourniquets (e.g., CAT) + universal tourniquet training
US civilian adoption date (approx.): 2013–2016 (Hartford Consensus 2013; Stop the Bleed launched Oct 2015; ACS bleeding-control courses Oct 2016)
Civilian adoption pathway (how it crosse: Hartford Consensus & Stop the Bleed promoted by ACS/DoD; integration into EMS/police kits; bystander training
Mechanism / What changed: Routine early extremity hemorrhage control with commercial windlass tourniquets; training non‑medics to apply rapidly
Reported impact on outcomes: Military: clear survival benefit and low morbidity (Kragh 2008); Civilian: systematic reviews show effectiveness with few complications; Boston Marathon analysis documented effective use

Innovation: Hemostatic dressings (kaolin-impregnated gauze; QuikClot Combat Gauze)
Military implementation date (approx.): 2008 (Combat Gauze widely adopted; earlier granular QuikClot circa 2002–2004)
Civilian adoption pathway (how it crosse: Included in law enforcement/EMS kits; Hartford Consensus recommendations; Stop the Bleed kits
Mechanism / What changed: Kaolin accelerates clotting; gauze format allows wound packing for junctional/irregular wounds
Reported impact on outcomes: Prehospital multicenter civilian study: QCG 89% effective; minimal morbidity (Leonard 2016); additional early civilian series support benefit

US civilian adoption date (approx.): 2010s via massive transfusion protocols (MTPs) in trauma centers; PROPPR 2015
Civilian adoption pathway (how it crosse: Academic trauma trials (PROPPR) and guidelines; hospital MTPs adopt balanced ratios
Mechanism / What changed: Early hemostatic resuscitation with plasma/platelets/RBCs ~1:1:1, minimal crystalloids; focus on stopping bleeding fast
Reported impact on outcomes: PROPPR: no diff in 24h/30d all‑cause mortality, but higher hemostasis and fewer deaths from exsanguination at 24h in 1:1:1 group

War/Theater origin: Derived from DCR experience in GWOT
US civilian adoption date (approx.): 2018 onward after PAMPer (NEJM 2018) and related trials; protocolized in many air/ground EMS
Civilian adoption pathway (how it crosse: Randomized civilian trials (PAMPer, COMBAT analyses); trauma system protocols for air medical units
Mechanism / What changed: Give thawed plasma before hospital to correct coagulopathy and reduce bleeding
Reported impact on outcomes: PAMPer: lower 30‑day mortality (23.2% vs 33.0%); benefit greatest with transport >20 min (post‑hoc)

Innovation: Prehospital low‑titer O whole blood (LTOWB) & WFWB concepts
US civilian adoption date (approx.): Mid‑2010s onward; EMS/trauma systems (e.g., San Antonio) implement LTOWB programs
Civilian adoption pathway (how it crosse: Regional EMS & trauma centers deploy LTOWB based on military data; registry/observational studies
Mechanism / What changed: Use of whole blood early to restore oxygen‑carrying capacity and hemostasis
Reported impact on outcomes: Civilian single‑center registry 2015–2019: prehospital LTOWB associated with lower early mortality in hemorrhagic shock

Innovation: Tranexamic acid (TXA) early use in trauma
War/Theater origin: Adopted globally; informed by both civilian mega‑trial and battlefield experience (MATTERs)
US civilian adoption date (approx.): 2010s; EMS & trauma protocols after CRASH‑2; 2025 US joint position statement endorses prehospital TXA in select shock
Civilian adoption pathway (how it crosse: CRASH‑2 (Lancet 2010) + US consensus statements (NAEMSP/ACS/ACEP 2025) and trauma guidelines
Mechanism / What changed: Antifibrinolytic inhibits clot breakdown; give within 3 h (earlier is better)
Reported impact on outcomes: CRASH‑2: reduced all‑cause mortality (RR 0.91) with early dosing; best if <3 h from injury

Innovation: REBOA (Resuscitative Endovascular Balloon Occlusion of the Aorta)
War/Theater origin: Iraq & Afghanistan (renewed interest building on earlier concepts)
US civilian adoption date (approx.): 2013 (first civilian case series) → ongoing 2010s–2020s adoption at select centers; prehospital pilots
Civilian adoption pathway (how it crosse: Military/academic exchange; trauma society training; device approvals
Mechanism / What changed: Temporary balloon occlusion to control non‑compressible torso hemorrhage while expediting definitive control
Reported impact on outcomes: Mixed; feasibility 68–100% prehospital in select series; survival to discharge reported but technique remains selective

Innovation: Needle decompression site change (4th/5th ICS anterior‑axillary line)
US civilian adoption date (approx.): 2010s; incorporated by many EMS/trauma protocols following TCCC
Civilian adoption pathway (how it crosse: Guideline harmonization; EMS medical directors update protocols
Mechanism / What changed: Move from 2nd ICS mid‑clavicular to lateral site to reduce failure from chest wall thickness and iatrogenic injury
Reported impact on outcomes: Guideline‑supported; improved success reported in implementation studies (protocol‑level evidence)

Innovation: Helicopter MEDEVAC, the 'Golden Hour', and air medical EMS
War/Theater origin: Korean War (first large‑scale helo medevac, 1951) → Vietnam War (systematized Golden Hour)
US civilian adoption date (approx.): 1970s onward (MAST program) → widespread air ambulance and trauma systems in 1980s–2000s
Civilian adoption pathway (how it crosse: DoD/DoT/HEW MAST program; state trauma system development led by ACS COT
Mechanism / What changed: Rapid evacuation to definitive care; creation of tiered trauma systems and air medical transport models
Reported impact on outcomes: Faster evacuation linked with improved survival; foundational to modern U.S. trauma systems

War/Theater origin: Lessons from GWOT TCCC applied to civilians
US civilian adoption date (approx.): 2013 Hartford Consensus → Oct 2015 national launch → 2016 ACS courses
Civilian adoption pathway (how it crosse: White House/ACS launch; licensing from DoD; nationwide public training & kit placement
Mechanism / What changed: Train bystanders to apply pressure, pack wounds with hemostatic gauze, and use tourniquets before EMS arrival
Reported impact on outcomes: Programmatic; widespread training and kit deployment; evidence extrapolated from military & civilian hemorrhage control studies
